content: "... My theme is the intellectual decline of conservatism, and it is notable that the policies of the new conservatism are powered largely by emotion and religion and have for the most part weak intellectual groundings. That the policies are weak in conception, have largely failed in execution, and are political flops is therefore unsurprising. The major blows to conservatism, culminating in the election and programs of Obama, have been fourfold: the failure of military force to achieve U.S. foreign policy objectives; the inanity of trying to substitute will for intellect, as in the denial of global warming, the use of religious criteria in the selection of public officials, the neglect of management and expertise in government; a continued preoccupation with abortion; and fiscal incontinence in the form of massive budget deficits, the Medicare drug plan, excessive foreign borrowing, and asset-price inflation. By the fall of 2008, the face of the Republican Party had become Sarah Palin and Joe the Plumber. Conservative intellectuals had no party. ..." "http://www.becker-posner-blog.com/archives/2009/05/is_the_conserva.html"

When Reagan made his famous speech at the Berlin Wall in 1987, and asked the Soviet Premier "to tear down this wall," he also used the term "liberalism." He was refering of course to Soviet totalitarianism, and was suggesting the Soviets take a more "liberal" approach to opening up - East-West relations. I had no problem with that premise, and still don't. Your problem is, and you've done this before with me; you peg me as a party loyalist while offering no different points of view. content: Please define "conservatism". Is a conservationist a conservative? Most conservationists I know would object at being labelled conservative. And of what brand of conservatism do you refer? Social conservatism? Fiscal? Paleo? Neo? Social conservatism is not a new concept, and has been supported by some of the greatest thinkers in history. Aquinas, Augustine, Lewis, Tolkien, Schaeffer, etc. Undoubtedly, it has also been challenged by some great minds too. Fiscal conservatism has as its modern champion Milton Friedman, who is the yang to Keynes' yin. There is just too much to get into between which model of fiscal philosophy is "right". Me...I prefer Friedman's model. It allows for far more individual autonomy regulated by the market and individual responsibility (i.e. moral and ethical restraint). I don't find as much support for neo-conservatism these days. But Paleo-conservatism is starting to gain in popularity. "Common sense was an uncommon virtue"

Let me be clear, I am not posting on this topic because I agree with some of the earlier posts or to bash conservatives/Republicans. That being said, you seem like the minority of conservatives. Just look at these boards. Anyone who is percieved to be a Democrat, or anything less than a hard core conservative is automatically labeled a "liberal facist socialist democrat progressive". Rush Limbaugh, Ann Coulter, and others have pushed people who have some conservative leanings away from the GOP. The hard liners have created a hostile environment for young people and minorities. They refuse to admit that they lost in 2006 and 2008 because the Bush version of conservatism was failing. They blaimed it on everything else. I am for a strict interpretation of the 2nd Amendment. It gives us the right to bare arms, bottom line. In theory, I am also for lower taxes, a strong military, strong national defense, and good foreign policy. But I haven't seen that happen with today's conservatives/Republicans. They've talked a great game, shouted really, but haven't done much but weaken the economy and mismanage two wars. That's why I came within a hair's breadth of voting for Obama and if I had it to do all over again, today I might actually choose him over John McCain (who is one of my all time favorite politicians). That's because John McCain was forced to appeal to Bush/Cheney-era conservatives, neocons, and was undercut every step of the way by the hard-line "conservatives". I wish to hell John McCain had gotten the nomination he rightfully deserved in 2000 and 2004. We'd be a lot better off right now.

content: quote: Wee's the list of leading Democratic presidential contenders: Algore, John F. Kerry, Tom F. Daschle, Joe F. Lieberman, John F. Edwards, Dick F. Gephardt, and Hillary F. R. Clinton. Now ask yourself: What do they all have in common? Answer: Not one of them has any serious business experience. Not one! They're either lawyers or career politicians. None of them has ever served as a governor - which is the chief executive officer of the state. None of them has a Harvard MBA like President Bush. The buck has never stopped at one of their desks. They've never had to attract businesses or jobs to their states by creating a healthy investment and business environment. Yet they're writing laws out there on accounting, and CEOs and corporations, and people applauding! This helps explain their constant disparagement and antipathy toward capitalism, business enterprise, private property, tax cuts and limited government. It helps explain their "them against us" rhetoric and their contempt for Bush and Cheney. Neither the president nor the vice president are lawyers or career pols, but both have succeeded in the business world. Compare that to these Democrats, who believe that rights are not natural or God-given, but rather come from government. These Democrats claim to be civil libertarians, yet they oppose free speech in so-called campaign finance reform. They oppose the free exercise of religion. They oppose freedom of association. They oppose gun ownership. They oppose individual rights and states' rights - all of which are explicitly protected in the Bill of Rights, and I mean the Bill of Rights. I don't mean Daschle's stupid investors' bill of rights or the patients' bill of rights or whatever else these clowns come up with to corrupt our language and dilute the real Bill of Rights. These Democrats attack Bush and Cheney, and seek to punish all businesses in the name of rooting out corruption. For all these reasons, they must be stopped. "Don't go back," as I write in Capitalism Does Not Lead to Corruption, Lack of Character Does. Do not allow this little blip in our market to turn you against capitalism. Don't fall for this notion that the pursuit of profit is what leads to corruption. People with no integrity or character are the ones who end up being corrupt. ===================== This was in 2004... but still made some good points. no. not good points at all. The topic is "the intellectual decline of conservatism". Not "Did these cherry picked democrats run a company?".

content: "... My theme is the intellectual decline of conservatism, and it is notable that the policies of the new conservatism are powered largely by emotion and religion and have for the most part weak intellectual groundings. That the policies are weak in conception, have largely failed in execution, and are political flops is therefore unsurprising. The major blows to conservatism, culminating in the election and programs of Obama, have been fourfold: the failure of military force to achieve U.S. foreign policy objectives; the inanity of trying to substitute will for intellect, as in the denial of global warming, the use of religious criteria in the selection of public officials, the neglect of management and expertise in government; a continued preoccupation with abortion; and fiscal incontinence in the form of massive budget deficits, the Medicare drug plan, excessive foreign borrowing, and asset-price inflation. By the fall of 2008, the face of the Republican Party had become Sarah Palin and Joe the Plumber. Conservative intellectuals had no party. ..." "http://www.becker-posner-blog.com/archives/2009/05/is_the_conserva.html"

Since you claim I know nothing about this subject I'll still play. 150 years ago, when Abraham Lincoln was president, the political stance he took back then, would have him pegged as a Democrat today. That's a pretty simple deduction if you look back upon the two different parties and their political platforms back then, as compared to now. When Reagan made his famous speech at the Berlin Wall in 1987, and asked the Soviet Premier "to tear down this wall," he also used the term "liberalism." He was refering of course to Soviet totalitarianism, and was suggesting the Soviets take a more "liberal" approach to opening up - East-West relations. I had no problem with that premise, and still don't. Your problem is, and you've done this before with me; you peg me as a party loyalist while offering no different points of view. content: Please define "conservatism". Is a conservationist a conservative? Most conservationists I know would object at being labelled conservative. And of what brand of conservatism do you refer? Social conservatism? Fiscal? Paleo? Neo? Social conservatism is not a new concept, and has been supported by some of the greatest thinkers in history. Aquinas, Augustine, Lewis, Tolkien, Schaeffer, etc. Undoubtedly, it has also been challenged by some great minds too. Fiscal conservatism has as its modern champion Milton Friedman, who is the yang to Keynes' yin. There is just too much to get into between which model of fiscal philosophy is "right". Me...I prefer Friedman's model. It allows for far more individual autonomy regulated by the market and individual responsibility (i.e. moral and ethical restraint). I don't find as much support for neo-conservatism these days. But Paleo-conservatism is starting to gain in popularity. "Common sense was an uncommon virtue"

content: quote: Originally posted by 2494906: quote: Originally posted by SenClaghorn: quote: Confusing conservatism with the Republican party. If they are not there, then where are they? It's really quiet simple... Conservatives will vote their conscience; not a party. Now... Right now in America, that most lines up with the Republican party. But Conservatives have left political parties before. Don't confuse the two. There are democrats that are more conservative than some republicans. I'd vote for them in a heartbeat. Let me be clear, I am not posting on this topic because I agree with some of the earlier posts or to bash conservatives/Republicans. That being said, you seem like the minority of conservatives. Just look at these boards. Anyone who is percieved to be a Democrat, or anything less than a hard core conservative is automatically labeled a "liberal facist socialist democrat progressive". Rush Limbaugh, Ann Coulter, and others have pushed people who have some conservative leanings away from the GOP. The hard liners have created a hostile environment for young people and minorities. They refuse to admit that they lost in 2006 and 2008 because the Bush version of conservatism was failing. They blaimed it on everything else. I am for a strict interpretation of the 2nd Amendment. It gives us the right to bare arms, bottom line. In theory, I am also for lower taxes, a strong military, strong national defense, and good foreign policy. But I haven't seen that happen with today's conservatives/Republicans. They've talked a great game, shouted really, but haven't done much but weaken the economy and mismanage two wars. That's why I came within a hair's breadth of voting for Obama and if I had it to do all over again, today I might actually choose him over John McCain (who is one of my all time favorite politicians). That's because John McCain was forced to appeal to Bush/Cheney-era conservatives, neocons, and was undercut every step of the way by the hard-line "conservatives". I wish to hell John McCain had gotten the nomination he rightfully deserved in 2000 and 2004. We'd be a lot better off right now.

content: The saying goes "the Party of Ideas has become the Party of Stupid" and it's absolutely true. There is no room for intellectuals in the conservative or Republican camps. They're considered "elitists" in this modern era. When it comes to the fixing the economy, somehow the modern conservative has been convinced to dismiss nobel prize winning economist while embracing phoney "everyday" plumbers. When it comes to the analyzing foreign policy, somehow the modern conservative has been convinced to dismiss diplomats and statesmen while while embracing the policies of Foxnews and talk radio pundits who've never lived outside the United States and don't speak other languages.

content: quote: Wee's the list of leading Democratic presidential contenders: Algore, John F. Kerry, Tom F. Daschle, Joe F. Lieberman, John F. Edwards, Dick F. Gephardt, and Hillary F. R. Clinton. Now ask yourself: What do they all have in common? Answer: Not one of them has any serious business experience. Not one! They're either lawyers or career politicians. None of them has ever served as a governor - which is the chief executive officer of the state. None of them has a Harvard MBA like President Bush. The buck has never stopped at one of their desks. They've never had to attract businesses or jobs to their states by creating a healthy investment and business environment. Yet they're writing laws out there on accounting, and CEOs and corporations, and people applauding! This helps explain their constant disparagement and antipathy toward capitalism, business enterprise, private property, tax cuts and limited government. It helps explain their "them against us" rhetoric and their contempt for Bush and Cheney. Neither the president nor the vice president are lawyers or career pols, but both have succeeded in the business world. Compare that to these Democrats, who believe that rights are not natural or God-given, but rather come from government. These Democrats claim to be civil libertarians, yet they oppose free speech in so-called campaign finance reform. They oppose the free exercise of religion. They oppose freedom of association. They oppose gun ownership. They oppose individual rights and states' rights - all of which are explicitly protected in the Bill of Rights, and I mean the Bill of Rights. I don't mean Daschle's stupid investors' bill of rights or the patients' bill of rights or whatever else these clowns come up with to corrupt our language and dilute the real Bill of Rights. These Democrats attack Bush and Cheney, and seek to punish all businesses in the name of rooting out corruption. For all these reasons, they must be stopped. "Don't go back," as I write in Capitalism Does Not Lead to Corruption, Lack of Character Does. Do not allow this little blip in our market to turn you against capitalism. Don't fall for this notion that the pursuit of profit is what leads to corruption. People with no integrity or character are the ones who end up being corrupt. ===================== This was in 2004... but still made some good points. no. not good points at all. The topic is "the intellectual decline of conservatism". Not "Did these cherry picked democrats run a company?".
